justification: De Wit (2009) states: “The most commonly used behavioral measures of impulsivity are delay discounting, which assesses impulsive decision-making…” indicating that delay-discounting tasks are taken as a measure of impulsivity.
The same De Wit (2009) sentence continues “…and behavioral-inhibition tasks,” explicitly listing behavioural-inhibition tasks as another measurement of impulsivity.

Hamilton et al. (2015) note that choice impulsivity “can be measured through indifference points, the discount rate, area under the curve, or… just by taking the percentage of larger later choices made,” directly tying these four indices to the construct.

measured_by: degree of delay discounting in intertemporal choice tasks
justification: The article observes that “it is customary across many domains of behavioural sciences to denote those who discount the future strongly as impulsive and those who do not as self-controlled,” showing that shallow delay-discounting (measured in intertemporal choice tasks) is treated as an index of self-control.
